case_vignette:
A 1-month-old girl presents to her pediatrician with her mother. The patient was born at 38 weeks gestation via Caesarian section for cervical incompetence. The patient’s mother has no complaints, although she notes that the child had a runny nose and cough for a few days last week. The patient’s mother endorses decreased appetite during the aforementioned illness which has now returned to baseline. The patient’s family history is significant for an older brother with glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency and a maternal uncle with cirrhosis secondary to chronic hepatitis B. On physical exam, the patient has scleral icterus and dark urine staining her diaper. Laboratory testing reveals the following:

Serum:
Na+: 137 mEq/L
Cl-: 102 mEq/L
K+: 4.2 mEq/L
HCO3-: 24 mEq/L
Urea nitrogen: 12 mg/dL
Glucose: 96 mg/dL
Creatinine: 0.36 mg/dL
Alkaline phosphatase: 146 U/L
Aspartate aminotransferase (AST): 86 U/L
Alanine aminotransferase (ALT): 76 U/L
Total bilirubin: 4.6 mg/dL
Direct bilirubin: 3.8 mg/dL
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?
correct_ans: obstruction of the extrahepatic biliary tree

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Pediatrics and Neonatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have yellowish eyes and my pee is really dark.
Have you had any fever or abdominal pain?
No, I haven't had any fever or tummy pain.
Have you had any recent changes in your appetite or weight?
My appetite went down when I was sick last week, but it's back to normal now.
Have you had any recent changes in your sleep patterns or energy levels?
No changes in my sleep or energy levels.
Have you had any recent travel or exposure to any new environments?
I haven't had any recent travel or been in new environments.
Have you had any recent changes in your diet or eating habits?
No, there haven't been any changes in what I eat.
Have you had any recent changes in your medication or supplements?
I haven't been taking any medications or supplements.
Have you had any recent changes in your family history or medical history?
I have an older brother with an enzyme deficiency and an uncle with liver problems from a chronic infection.
Final Diagnosis: Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome (HUS)

trial_0.summarized_conversation: A patient presents with yellowish eyes and dark urine, without fever or abdominal pain. They experienced a decreased appetite when sick last week, but it has since returned to normal. There have been no changes in sleep or energy levels, recent travel, new environments, or diet. The patient has not been taking any medications or supplements. They have an older brother with an enzyme deficiency and an uncle with liver problems from a chronic infection.
trial_0.vignette_frq: The most likely diagnosis is neonatal jaundice with hemolytic disease of the newborn (HDN).
